video.title: Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Yahtzee, Yahtzee, Yahtzee, Yahtzee. Why do you 
keep doing this to yourself? So you liked Modern

Warfare 1. Surely you didn&#39;t like it enough 
to still be holding out hope at this point.

You&#39;re like the dude whose goose laid one golden 
egg and spent the next 20 years sticking their

head up random geese&#39;s arses. Firstly, they&#39;re 
called cloaca. Secondly, while I&#39;ve certainly

given up on Modern Warfare because I get 
enough chest-thumping self-righteousness

from listening to silverback gorillas at the zoo 
reviewing the latest Marvel movies at each other,

I still hold out a sliver of hope for 
Black Ops. Black Ops 6 was pretty awful,

but that one moment with the daring escape 
on American flag-decorated motorbikes made

me think that if this series keeps going on, 
then sooner or later, it&#39;s going to cross

the Resident Evil event horizon and become 
knowingly camp rather than laughably bad,

and that, friends, is where some true magic 
could happen. But while I find it hard to

believe anyone involved genuinely took the Black 
Ops 7 campaign seriously—I mean, a previous Black

Ops protagonist turns into a giant plant monster 
and then you fight an evil Kaiju-sized Michael

Rooker—none of it was laughably bad. Laughter 
was the furthest thing from my mind, actually.

The main question I&#39;ve been quietly seething 
about is why, after all these years of being

proved wrong on this, Call of Duty—and indeed 
AAA games generally—still can&#39;t internalize the

notion that some people want single player. And 
don&#39;t want sequels to single-player games to be

multiplayer focused. It&#39;s fucking wedding party 
DJ syndrome again, isn&#39;t it? &quot;Come on down and

dance in front of everyone! You want to, really! 
Don&#39;t be such a stick in the mud!&quot; The only stick

in the mud around here, mate, is going to be 
this broom handle after I shove it up your

arse. Black Ops 7 plays its hand on the fucking 
title menu. The only options are &quot;multiplayer&quot;

or &quot;co-op campaign.&quot; You can play single player; 
the game just refuses to admit it. You have to go

through the fucking matchmaking screen, hunt 
through terrible GUI menus, and set yourself

to &quot;Appear Offline&quot; to get a single-player game 
going. Even then, I still wasn&#39;t allowed to pause

the game and kept hearing mysterious snatches 
of other people&#39;s voice chat for some reason,

like I&#39;d accidentally opened a gateway into 
the secret hell for extremely boring people.

It wouldn&#39;t start in offline mode and even then 
still refused me entry until I went into my

PC&#39;s fucking BIOS options and turned on something 
called Secure Boot in aid of their slightly shady

anti-cheat thingy. &quot;Yes, Yahtzee, and now you 
want all that effort to have been for nothing!&quot;

Anyway, the story concerns Peter Petrelli off 
of Heroes as a dutiful soldier man apparently

incapable of separating his teeth while 
speaking, and he&#39;s part of a—yeah, sing along,

you all know the words—covert special ops military 
unit representing an unclear authority who must

battle the machinations of an evil private 
military corporation who are engineering a

secret bioweapon that they intend to drop on 
civilian targets in order to foment global

conflict off of which they can subsequently 
profit. And since it&#39;s a co-op campaign,

Peter Petrelli of course suffers from that strange 
affliction where he keeps imagining the voices of

three other characters who magically pop out of 
his arse during cutscenes because who&#39;s got time

to program bots with all these functionally 
identical assault rifles that need polishing?

Your teammates include Michael Rooker, and then to 
counteract the established wall of angry white guy

energy, a reasonable black dude and a slightly 
less reasonable lady dude. Don&#39;t look to any

of these twats for much in the way of distinct 
personality; a token effort is made to establish

Michael Rooker as the facetious one, but besides 
that, I marked several occasions where the main

characters changed their entire stance on the 
situation from one dialogue line to the next.

I assume the game adjusts numbers of enemies based 
on number of players, so the game&#39;s quite playable

solo, barring a couple of moments where we&#39;re 
expected to defend a point while enemies swarm

in from all directions, which would usually end 
with me running around in circles being chased

by a small horde like a child having a severe 
falling out with their balloon. Maybe the devs

thought it best to discourage solo play &#39;cause 
they were afraid without the distraction of other

players teabagging the corpses and talking over 
the cutscenes to ask if you know what&#39;s going on,

we might notice that the story&#39;s a load of old 
wank-sodden supermarket own-brand paper towels. We

attack the evil private military corporation and 
get a faceful of the bioweapon they&#39;re working on,

and it turns out that it&#39;s Scarecrow fear gas. 
And isn&#39;t it nice that I can say that and you

immediately know what I&#39;m talking about; who 
says there&#39;s no monoculture anymore? So of

course we start wildly hallucinating mental 
realms based on our characters&#39; memories;

apparently the stupid floating platform 
mental realm mission at the end of Black

Ops 6 was more a proof of concept than 
an awkward hard left out of nowhere,

and what follows is a sort of hallucinatory love 
letter to the Black Ops series thus far—only don&#39;t

call it a love letter lest you undermine 
the game&#39;s alpha male testosterone levels.

So, we touch base with various previous 
protagonists going through hallucinatory

floaty platform versions of important moments, 
which is where the plant monster thing happens,

although the giant Michael Rooker incident 
doesn&#39;t even have that level of justification,

and interact with good old Alex Mason from Black 
Ops 1 who is Peter Petrelli&#39;s dad. And I couldn&#39;t

help laughing at the bit where we go through his 
childhood memories and learn that Alex Mason lived

in a fucking log cabin in the woods. And we see 
idyllic and wholesome memories of him teaching his

son to fish and clean a rifle and most optimally 
torture foreigners extralegally. At this point,

the gameplay designer must have kicked down the 
story department&#39;s door and went, &quot;It&#39;s co-op,

you idiots! How the fuck are all the players 
hallucinating the same thing?&quot; &quot;Oh, shit! Er...

their brains are all connected. Yeah, that works. 
It&#39;s a super secret military technology they have,

presumably developed by someone who was a 
really bad conversationalist.&quot; So in summary,

the story is really fucking dumb, the heroes 
are boring, and the smug villain with her army

of masked stormtroopers have all the depth and 
moral complexity of fucking Cobra Commander,

and it all culminates in blowing up an 
underwater tech base James Bond style.

But things don&#39;t end there. Post-credits, I 
took the wrong exit on my way to the title

menu and suddenly found myself in what looked 
like a Ubisoft sandbox. You go back to one of

the previous maps from the campaign, which I 
remember thinking at the time was weirdly large

for what little we were doing in it, only now 
we&#39;ve got a map spattered with icons and can go

around doing little mini combat challenges to 
fill out the checklist. And out of curiosity,

I pissed about in it for a while, wondering 
if &quot;Ubisoft sandbox&quot; was the last thing the

developers had needed to throw in to fill out 
their &quot;overly bloated shit AAA game&quot; bingo card,

but was startled to see a random dude with an 
icon over their head run past, who didn&#39;t react

when I shot him, and it was only after I noticed 
him teabag a fallen stormtrooper that I realized,

&quot;Hey, what the fuck?! That&#39;s a human player! Did 
you just wordlessly drop me into a multiplayer

mode without asking, Black Ops 7?&quot; This is 
beyond the pale. Now the wedding party DJ

has started roofieing me fucking drinks. Do 
I have to write &quot;appear offline&quot; across my

fucking forehead? Take a fucking hint. 
I&#39;m just not that into you, human race.
